sn5.5:4.2: Then the nun Uppalavaṇṇā got dressed in the morning …
sn5.5:4.3: and stood at the root of a sal tree in full flower.
sn5.5:4.4: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the nun Uppalavaṇṇā feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make her fall away from convergence,
sn5.5:4.5: went up to her and addressed her in verse:
sn5.5:5.1: “You’ve come to this sal tree all crowned with flowers
sn5.5:5.2: and stand at its root all alone, O nun.
sn5.5:5.3: Your beauty is second to none;
sn5.5:5.4: silly girl, aren’t you afraid of rascals?”
sn5.5:6.2: “Who’s speaking this verse, a human or a non-human?”
sn5.5:6.4: “This is Māra the Wicked, wanting to make me feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, wanting to make me fall away from convergence!”
sn5.5:6.5: Then Uppalavaṇṇā, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
sn5.5:7.3: I’d stir not a hair nor be alarmed.
sn5.5:7.4: I’m not scared of you, Māra, even alone.
sn5.5:8.3: I could stand between your eyebrows
sn5.5:8.4: and you still wouldn’t see me.
sn5.5:9.1: I’m the master of my own mind,
sn5.5:9.2: I’ve developed the bases of psychic power well.
sn5.5:9.4: and I’m not afraid of you, sir!”
sn5.5:10.1: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The nun Uppalavaṇṇā knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
